reviewText:
HARRY CAREY SENIOR AND FRANKIE DARRO DO A GOOD JOB ON THIS POVERTY ROW SERIAL ABOUT A MUTE BOY, A HORSE,
A COWBOY, SOME OUTLAWS, AND A MIRACLE. WELL WORTH THE MONEY TO GET THROUGH THE MYSTERY

"The Devil Horse" is a 12-chapter Mascot serial from 1932, directed by Otto Brower, with story by George Morgan, Barney Sarecky, George Plympton and Wyndham Gittens.

Two horse thieves, Canfield and Boyd (Noah Beery, Sr. and John Paul Jones) had robbed and killed a rancher (Lew Kelly), whose young son (Carli Russell, a.k.a. Carl R. Botefuhr, age 6) then grew up with wild horses.  Now known as the "Wild Boy" (Frankie Darro), he again encounters the two villains, who have become "respectable citizens," a rancher and a banker.  This time they kill a state ranger, Elliott Norton (Lane Chandler) while trying to steal a race horse, El Diablo (Apache) who escapes and joins the wild herd.  The dead ranger's older brother, Bob (Harry Carey), also a State Ranger, goes after the outlaws, encountering not only the Wild Boy, but also a mysterious band of horsemen, trying to capture the "devil horse" for Canfield, who seem to have some connection with Linda Weston (Greta Granstedt) and her brother Lee (Barrie O'Daniels).  Bob Norton discovers that his brother's death was witnessed by the Wild Boy, who unfortunately has forgotten how to speak.

The plot has similarities to that of the earlier Mascot serial "The Vanishing Legion."  There are strong performances by both the hero and chief villain, and remarkable stunt work including some by Yakima Canutt.  No question for the audience as to the identity of the main bad guys, but the mysterious horsemen provide a guessing game in the early chapters.  The "Wild Boy" variant on Tarzan takes some suspension of disbelief, especially his knowing only the language of the horses when he was doing well enough at English before his father's death.  But issues of this kind are easily overlooked with the serial-movie format of one chapter per week.  The fight scenes are as expected from Mascot, with a lot of arm-swinging and no background music -- sound mixing was a problem for small film producers in 1932 -- and surprisingly Harry Carey doesn't always win, even when only a couple bad guys are involved.  Also typical for a Mascot serial, there are quite a few "flashbacks" with rerun action footage from previous chapters.  Several serial and "B" western regulars are present, including Al Bridge as chief henchman Curley Bates, Jack Mower as Vigilante leader Mark Adams, Edward Peil, Sr. as the Sheriff, and in the first chapter William Desmond as the Ranger Captain.

The familiar theme music, from Rossini's "William Tell" overture, is an earlier usage than "The Lone Ranger," which didn't air on radio until a couple months after this serial was released.  Other "classical" music is used, occasionally mixed with the dialogue.  The introductions, which describe all the murders, violence and mayhem of the previous chapters, are accompanied by a rather cheerful section of the overture to Herold's "Zampa."  Lee Zahler was the music director for this serial.

Alpha's DVD edition, # ALP 5617D is on a single disc, and while the image isn't too bad for an Alpha release, it isn't very sharp and it looks a little muddy, though the highlights don't wash out.  Sometimes there is ripple in the intensity and quite a bit of video noise.  The print shows occasional fading, some splices interrupt the sound, though mostly during the chapter introductions, and one of the "next week" titles was "recreated" along with another title in Chapter One.  There are some rough "splices" from video editing where the opening credits join the chapter titles.  The image is framed fairly well, though in some of the "last week" text the final line goes partially off-screen.  The sound is a worse problem; while the dialogue isn't hard to understand, there is dynamic compression of the "auto-level" variety, so the background noise becomes quite loud and it makes a real mess of percussive effects such as gunshots, which often vanish in the sonic fog.  Some extra sound effects have been added to try to compensate for these defects, mostly horse noises, but it wasn't done well, the sudden appearance of high frequencies is all too obvious.  On this release Alpha does not put their logo in the frame during all of the credits, but includes a copyright notice for the "special edition" during the opening titles, less annoying even if it covers the original credit for Disney Film Recording Co.

VCI's old VHS edition, # 1733 is from a different video source.  It has a sharper picture, and after viewing Alpha's DVD it is a joy to watch.  While not ideal either, with chapters Ten and Eleven having some horizontal jitter noticed mostly in the titles, the gray scale is better than Alpha's, and the sound far more representative of what was possible in 1932 films, with gunshots sounding pretty much as they should, and the background hiss is mostly at a constant low level.  Further, the film is more complete, the first chapter running a minute and a half longer, and the titles that had to be recreated by Alpha are present in their original form.  The framing is about the same as Alpha's, though different chapters have the slightly off-screen text.

This is a good Mascot serial, which should be of interest to fans of Harry Carey and Noah Beery, but much as I would like to encourage Alpha's attempts at restoration, their release has little to recommend it over VCI's VHS edition, other than availability and that it fits better in a DVD player.  It is better than many from Alpha and fairly cheap, so it might do for those curious about the serial and tolerant of poor sound, but the serial deserves a better DVD transfer.

The only connection between ALPHA's serial version of THE DEVIL HORSE and the silent film of 8 years earlier is Yakima Canutt-- he starred in the original and directs the 2nd unit on this one. These westerns are quite different plotwise (the 1926 movie was scripted by Stan Laurel!). OUR STORY: A gang, led by a respectable rancher, raids a remote cabin, killing all but one member of the family-- a child who escapes to grow up both feral and unable to speak, among a number of wild horses. Some years later, a Ranger is murdered and his brother seeks the killers. Beset by the outlaws, a vigilante group and a wild horse called El Diablo, the man turns for aid to the "Wild Boy." CAST-- Harry Carey - Bob Norton Noah Beery - Canfield Frankie Darro - The Wild Boy Greta Granstedt - Linda Weston Barrie O'Daniels - Lee Weston Edward Peil Sr. - The Sheriff Jack Mower - Mark Adams Al Bridge - Curley Bates Jack Byron - Jake CHAPTERS-- 1)- Untamed 2)- The Chasm of Death 3)- The Doom Riders 4)- Vigilante Law 5)- The Silent Call 6)- The Heart of the Mystery 7)- The Battle of the Strong 8)- The Missing Witness 9)- The Showdown 10) The Death Trap 11) Wild Loyalty 12) The Double Decoy Western serial fans will definitely enjoy THE PAINTED STALLION, with Ray Corrigan, Hoot Gibson and Duncan Renaldo. DEVIL HORSE TRIVIA-- The film career of Western superstar Harry Carey (Bob Norton) began in 1909. He worked with great directors like Griffith, Hawks and Ford. When Carey died in 1947 he was buried in a cowboy outfit. Noah Beery (Canfield) was Wallace's older brother. He specialized in playing villains. Frankie Darro (Wild Boy) was the son of circus aerialists. He never grew taller than 5' 3" so Darro was forced to do all his own stunts (there was no one his size to double for him). After his acting career ended, Darro became a stuntman himself. Al Bridge (Curley Bates) often played the bad guy in Hopalong Cassidy programmers. El Diablo was portrayed by Apache; the horse was also western 'B' film star Bob Baker's mount. Yakima Canutt got no screen credit as both "Slim" and a henchman. Also in uncredited parts: Lane Chandler and Robert Walker.

VCI Entertainment and Mascot Pictures present  "The Devil Horse" (1932) (Dolby digitally remastered), with 12 Chapters of vintage serial episodes jam packed with thrilling action sequences and stunts that will keep you on the edge of your seat...story line follows crooked horse racing led by the respected Canfield (Beery) who in reality has an outlaw gang bent on raiding every rancher in the territory...our hero Bob Norton (Carey) and the wild boy (Darro) are searching for the men who killed Elliott Norton (Lane Chandler) Bob's brother...now enters the Devil Horse who never leaves the wild boy's side for protection against all who do him harm, this is the horse that Canfield is after for his own benefit....will the speechless wild boy who grew up with wild horses be able to point out the real villains...can this Mascot Serial keep the action, daring stunt-work and an exciting cliffhanger going the entire serial....check out Noah Beery's over acting that pays off in every scene, another winner for the villains of villains....but don't leave the theater until the final chapter is over and done with "The Double Decoy"....just remember double thrills, chills, mystery and suspense...hitting the bull's eye with excitement...don't miss a single spine thrilling episode..return next week to this local theater for another episode of action and adventure that will keep you thrilled until the next chapter.

Under director Otto Brower, producer Nat Levine, Original screenplay by George Morgan, Barney A. Sarecky,  George H. Plympton and Wyndham Gittens, musical score by Lee Zahler...the cast includes Harry Carey (Bob Norton), Noah Beery (Canfield), Frankie Darro (The Wild Boy), Apache (the devil horse), Greta Granstedt (Linda Weston), Barrie O'Daniels (Lee Weston), Edward Peil Sr The Sheriff), Jack Mower (Mark Adams), Al Bridge (Curley Bates), Jack Bryon (Jake), J. Paul Jones (Matthew Boyd), Yakima Canutt (Slim-henchman), Lane Chandler (Elliott Norton)...the Mascot stuntmen with Yakima Canutt, Ken Cooper, Cliff Lyons, Richard Talmadge......meanwhile back to our Mascot Serial which is always good till the last drop and this serial is no exception...there is a great deal of entertainment here for the cliffhanger fans out there...all courtesy of VCI Entertainment, who in my humble opinion is the best there is in restoring early serials and features.

CHAPTER TITLES:
1.  Untamed
2.  The Chasm of Death
3.  The Doom Riders
4.  Vigilante Law
5.  The Silent Call
6.  The Heart of the Mystery
7.  The Battle of the Strong
8.  The Missing Witness
9.  The Showdown
10. The Death Trap
11. Wild Loyalty
12. The Double Decoy

BIOS:
1. Harry Carey
Birth Date: 1/16/1878 - Bronx, New York
Died: 9/21/1947 - Brentwood, CA
2. Noah Beery Sr.
Birth Date: 1/17/1882 - Kansas City, Missouri
Died: 4/01/1946 - Beverly Hills, CA
3.  Frankie Darro  (aka Frank Johnson)
Birth Date: 12/22/1917 - Chicago, Illinois
Died: 12/25/1976 - Huntington Beach, CA
4. Yakima Canutt (aka Enos Edward Canutt)
Birth Date: 11/29/1896 - Colfax, Washington
Died: 5/24/1986 - North Hollywood, CA
5.  Otto Brower (Director)
Birth Date: 12/02/1895 - Grand Rapids, Michigan
Died: 1/25/1946 - Hollywood, CA

If you're into vintage serials as I am, why not pick up a copy of the following titles from VCI Home Video:
VCI CLIFFHANGER TRAILERS:
1. Buck Rogers (Buster Crabbe)
2. Adventures of the Flying Cadets (Bobby Jordan)
3. Drums of Fu Manchu (Henry Brandon)
4. Jungle Girl (Frances Gifford)
5. The Phantom (Tom Tyler)
6. Zane Greys "King of the Royal Mounted" (Allan "Rocky" Lane)
7. Secret Agent X-9 (1945) (Lloyd Bridges & Keye Luke)
8. Adventures of Red Ryder (Don "Red" Barry)
9. Secret Agent X-9 (1937) (Scott Kolk & Henry Brandon)
10. Zorro's Cliffhanger Collection (Reed Hadley, John Carroll & Linda Stirling)
11. Dick Tracy's G-Men (Ralph Byrd)
12. Flash Gordon Conquers the Universe (Buster Crabbe)
13. Jungle Jim (Grant Withers & Raymond Hatton)
14. Miracle Rider (Tom Mix & Tony Jr)

If you crave action, drama and plenty of adventure then this is the place for all of the above...check out another release from VCI Entertainment and Republic Pictures present Zane Grey's "King of the Royal Mounted" (1940) (digitally remastered), 12 Chapters of vintage serial loaded with action sequences...is there a discovered substance called "Compound X", which may cure infantile paralysis...has Tom Merritt stumbled on such a rare find...is there a war between Canada and sources known later as the "Father Land".....get out there as they're going fast, this is the one you've been waiting for.

Great job by VCI Entertainment for releasing "The Devil Horse" (1932), the digital transfere with a clean, clear and crisp print...looking forward to more high quality releases from the vintage serial era of the '30s, '40s & '50s...order your copy now from Amazon or VCI Entertainment where there are plenty of copies available on VHS, stay tuned once again for top notch action mixed with deadly adventure from the "King of Serials" VCI...just the way we like 'em

Total Time: 216 mins on 2 VHS ~ VCI Entertainment 1733 ~ (11/01/2000)
